Colleagues, I want to thank you all for making time for this special city council meeting, have a couple of bills that are of an urgent need related to the cities emergency response to the Covid-19 public health pandemic and crisis that is taking place, not just in our city, in our region and state, but across the country and across the world.

Before we get started, we did want to recognize that we are having this conversation in the context of knowing that there are additional Covid-19 Diagnoses that are being made every day, and in fact today the State Department of health announced 175 new cases bringing the state total--I'm sorry, that new case count as of yesterday bringing the state total as of yesterday to 1187 cases, including 66 deaths.

Of course, out of the 66 deaths, the bulk of those are here in King County, where we have seen 56 individuals lose their lives to this unfortunate virus, and we have 562 people who have fallen ill to the Coronavirus right here in King County.
So, I wanted to take a moment, if you will join me for just a quick moment, to acknowledge the fact that we are continuing to lose lives, unfortunately and seeing people fall ill.

And I want to take time and honor those families who have been impacted by a lost loved ones, and for all of us who are very concerned about this to take a moment of silence, to acknowledge the lives that we have lost in our community.
I want to thank you all for giving me the opportunity to take that point of personal privilege.

I know that many of us have people who have been touched by this, and who will be touched by this unfortunate pandemic and I really do appreciate your willingness to publicly, via telephone, acknowledge the lives that we have lost on the lives that have been impacted.
We are going to go ahead and dig into our business today as I mentioned we only have two items, I am going to ask for the clerk to read item number one, will the clerk read item one?

City Council agenda 57, stopping the 2020 budget, and executive departments office of economic development, at budget control levels, and for various budgets for the purpose of providing financial assistance to small businesses and ratifying searching.
He

Requiring five votes in the affirmative, what I will do is move to cut past the Council bill, then I will ask for a second, and once that second has been made, we do have Council central staff on the line available for questions, I will go ahead and suspend the rules to allow for questions to be directed to Council central staff if any Councilmembers have it, or if the sponsor which is Council member Tammy Morales wants to provide counsel central staff with an opportunity to speak to the bill as well.
I will go through those motions, I will allow Councilmember Morales to address the bill, and then take a vote on any amendments.
I moved to pass Council bill 11957 point
Second.
Second.
It has been moved and Seconded to pass the bill.

After the prime sponsor speaks to the bill.

Would you like to address this bill?

Thank you.

I would like to take just a moment, I do want to acknowledge that the staff at the office of economic development have been working tirelessly, as have all of our frontline folks, who work for this city.
I do want to acknowledge the hard work that they are putting in to help us.
We sometimes get hourly new information about this crisis.

You know, our staff are hearing from small businesses who are worried about their employees, worried about their own businesses, and they are stealing themselves now with some secondary trauma from hearing those stories over and over again.
So, I want to thank our city employees who are helping us navigate through what is really an unprecedented time.
And, I want to thank the Mayor, and director Lee for getting this bill to us quickly.
This is an expansion of the existing funds that we have at the office of economic development.

It is shifting about $1.4 million in community development block grant and fund to provide emergency working capital grant, to small businesses, really Micro businesses who have five or fewer employees.

Because the funds are HUD funds, they require that the household income of the recipients be below 80 percent of area media income, so just some context for who will be receiving these grants, and they are roughly, you know, up to $10,000, to provide some sort of relief for working capital, and being able to pay employees or pay rent.
To manage as best as they can.
Thank you Councilmember Morales.
Anything else you would like to add before I go to the next step?
Didn't think so.

I would love it if counsel central staff or the viewing public and the press he might be reporting on this canvas very quickly go through, the Cbd G funds program for another purpose if we could just go quickly through what those purposes were, and how departments are going to accommodate whether or not there is a need for those purposes as originally anticipated, or there is another source.
Thank you, this is Amy Gore of the Council central staff.
To answer that question approximately $400,000 of the funds, of program administration.
Approximately 1 million of the funds being transferred by the Council bill are the human services departments community facilities program.
And then the intention of that funding was for community care facilities for seniors as part of the North lot project.
At the pack met center in beacon Hill.
And, what we have heard is that the project is not quite ready to use those funds in 2020, and is okay with us using those funds for a different purpose.
So, we believe that in 2020 one or 2022, we have other funds that we can devote to that time we can devote to the project more useful funds.
Thank you, Amy, for that explanation.

It absolutely did, thank you.

I do have one question, Yolanda was looking at, my understanding is that the intent is to use kind of a lottery system for awarding, because we have so many small businesses and people who have applied, I wonder if there is any additional information about how this process will work.

I can tell you that the lottery is going to be a weighted lottery system, so that the office of economic development has stated that, their goal is that 80 percent of these awards go through the neighborhoods at highest risk of businesses and neighborhoods that are at highest risk of displacement.
Thank you.

Great, thank you so much to counsel central staff for that description of the bill and follow-up, the answers to some of these questions, and thank you to Councilmember Morales for questions and detail.
I know particularly protections of small businesses are very important, and that you have continued to Prioritize those issues and this is certainly an important moment to continue doing that work.
I also understand that you have an amendment, to the bill, so we will go ahead and consider your amendment first.
And then, we will go ahead and vote on the underlying bill, if and once it is amended.
So, I will open up the floor to you, Councilmember Morales, to make your motion to amend the bill.
Thank you.
So, as Yolanda said, we do have lots of businesses who are very worried about how they will survive the crisis.
And, this is going to be an important fund to help for a couple of hundred businesses, so I understand we need to move quickly.
And, I worry, but in our case, we react to the crisis that we might set in motion some systems that will perpetuate inequities in our city.
So, I just want to make sure we have an equitable process for awarding these funds, and any other funding that we make available to Seattleites in response to this crisis.
So, we have I think about 36,000 small businesses in Seattle, thousands of them are owned by people who don't speak English.

Applications for this fund were available Online, but only in English, if you speak English you can fill out the application Online, and hit send, but it was a couple of days before they were made available, in other languages on the Online application had to be printed out and mailed in are handed in, to an outreach.
When those who don't speak English have extra barriers put in place in order to produce a bit, we know that we have got some issues.

And, I know that there was not any mail intent here, what we have instead is a small example of how, you know, very often are city government operates with Blinders on to anyone who is not a part of the dominant culture and we really have to change the way our city functions, so that everyone has access to these resources is a rather than slow down the disbursement of this particular fund I am asking that we hear back from Oed this summer about how the funds were distributed, you know, how many applicants did we get from people who don't speak English.
How many were awarded to folks who don't speak English, and just making sure that you know, non-English speakers also get access to these opportunities.

So if we are going to live up to our social justice goals, we have to be thoughtful about improving every aspect of our work and especially as we create the emergency responses to the crisis, I think it is really incumbent upon us to make sure that we are not perpetuating systems of inequity.

Even if it means that we slow down our response a little bit, we really need to make sure that people of color, low income folks, limited English speakers have access to the information they need, so that they can receive emergency relief, and so, that is the spirit in which this amendment is offered, it is not a requirement that Oed provides the report it is merely a request that we hear back from them about how this money was distributed.
Thank you for that description of the amendment, Councilmember Morales, I still need you to move the amendments.
I move that we adopt amendment one.
Great.

Agenda item 2, counsel bill 119758, relating to the city light and Seattle public utilities Department, temporarily removing the charge of interest on the link with utility consumption and utilization accounts.

Superseding several sections under title 21 that authorized and require the collection of interest on delinquent utility consumption and utilization accounts, declaring an emergency and establishing an immediate effective date by the city council.

Thank you to the clerk for that we will go through the same process we did with item number one, so, I will move to pass it, I will need a second, and then we will go ahead and invite the prime sponsor, council member Pearson, to speak to the bill, we will then suspend the rules to allow Údissent central staff to address the Council and answer any questions . Councilmember Peterson, and I believe Councilmember Lewis have some substitutions and an amendment, and then we will go ahead and consider those and then vote on the full bill, so that is the run of show as they say for this particular item.
So, I'm going to move to pass counsel bill 119758.
Second.
Moved and Seconded to pass the bill.

Again, Councilmembers please note that Eric Mcconaughey and of central staff have joined us meeting should you have any questions, I will move to suspend the rules if there are any questions for central spat central staff after the prime sponsor speaks to the bill.
Has never Peterson would you like to address this bill?
Yes, welcome back Council President Gonzalez, and thank you for leading with the moment of silence for all of those suffering from the Covid-19 emergency.
With this of course.
With this public health emergency becoming an economic crisis, too, all levels of government need to provide immediate financial relief.
And, that includes relief from utility bills that all households and small businesses and Nonprofits face each month.

With necessary public health protocols resulting in restaurants, Cafcs and other social establishments closing, many of our neighbors are seeing reduced paychecks or layoff and the last thing they need to worry about our bills for essentials like electricity, water, and garbage removal.
This legislation I'm sponsoring, counsel bill 119758 will waive all late fees for utility bills, to provide additional relief for hundreds of thousands throughout Seattle during this crisis.
In addition, I would also like to commend Deborah Smith of Seattle city light and the head of Seattle public utilities.
This effort builds upon a separate policy of no shutoff switch is a humane policy that our utility Department put in place in large part due to the leadership of counsel and Mosqueda.
I also want to thank Councilmember Andrew Lewis for requesting an amendment that we will consider shortly.
That'll make it click pistol clear that nonprofit 501 (c) (3) organizations would also benefit from this legislation.

This origin ordinance would waive late fees and interest charges from both Seattle city light, Seattle public utilities, until the Mayor's emergency declaration is terminated, on August 1, whichever comes first.
If the Covid-19 emergency last beyond August 1 the Council can take additional action to extend this waiver.
So, I am prepared to move the substitute and I can explain that.
But, let me know if that is the appropriate time?

I think what we are going to do first is, I will go ahead and suspend the rules to allow counsel central staff to address the Council, if they need to, and then we can go ahead and move through the substitution.

Under the Covid-19 crisis, it might just be a good standard practice, for all of these revenue impacts, to ask CBO, whether or not the actions that we are taking, that have financial impacts are actions that we can receive reimbursement for under Covid- 19.

Thank you Council President, first I want to thank Councilmember Peterson for all of the work that you are doing for those who are on limited incomes already and especially thinking about them in a post coded world as it relates to families and businesses, given the financial effects of public health crisis could have.

I want to also command the folks at Seattle city light who we have been engaged with sense last year, thank you for the shout out last year Councilmember Peterson and a huge shadow to the folks at Seattle city light for their creative thinking, not only stopping the mention of shut off notices but to be really open and receptive to community feedback on how to improve a number of their notices.

I think our counsel colleagues will be able to hear a number of provisions they put into place, waving late fees is a really great first step, and some of the other things we are looking at that really appreciates and will find the language to make sure especially in times like these to ensure we are using language that is inviting to understand the ways that payments can be done.
I'm looking forward to future conversations, about basically debt Forgiveess at some point, given some of the conversations that have happened in other municipalities.

As I say that I also recognize we need to be looking at the revenue impacts, and in our conversations with the budget director, we have been asking a number of questions about executive orders and I really appreciate the suggestions from our colleagues to make sure that is presented as we look at the various executive orders, I will echo that call and look forward to the future conversations about how we not only address the crisis, now, but make sure that we are budgeting for the future recovery of that.
The funding is going especially to the crisis, I think this is an excellent example that I have drawn on those priorities and values, so thank you again Council member Peterson.
And thank you for your good work on this.

Obviously district 7, has a massive concentration of arts organizations in the city.

The arts are really reeling from the response to Covid-19, given that so many of our artistic events involve gatherings of large numbers of people, they have just been absolutely slammed, it's an industry with a lot of workers who as we know Unfortunately do not receive Renumeration that they should for the cultural contributions they make.
So, the particularly vulnerable population.
One thing that has come up and talking to arts organizations in my district as the utilities are an ongoing concern for them, most of them are organized as mission driven Nonprofits.
So I wanted to make sure that the opportunities that we are looking to create can provide relief through the ordinance.
Be set up in such a way that those arts organizations could take advantage of those as well.
So, I want to thank Council member Peterson for his leadership.
It's been good to work with him on this over the last couple of days.
